prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(14-13) J1319
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main goal is to detect the CO(14-13) in J1319. This object has been already observed by ALMA in Cycle 2 at the frequency of the CO(14-13) line, but no detection has been obtained. However, current upper limits on the CO(14-13) are not stringent enough to make any claim on the excitation conditions of molecular gas in J1319. With the achievement of this science goal we will conclusively discriminate between PDR and XDR models.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Although from Fig. 1 it can be seen that in this object CO lines with 11 < J < 13 can already conclusively discriminate between PDR and XDR models, there are no ALMA receivers that can detect these lines, since their observed frequencies fall between ALMA BAND4 and ALMA BAND6.
Using the [CII] line redshift resulting from ALMA Cycle 0, we expect the CO(14-13) line to be at a frequency of 225.96292 GHz, that is the representative frequency of this Science Goal.
In the same sideband, we put one other SPW for the continuum determination.
Also the remaining two SPWs are used for the continuum determination and put in the other sideband.
The requested spectral resolution of 41 km/s is enough for the purpose of this Science Goal, since the FWHM of the line is expected to be ~ 537 km/s.

We request an angular resolution of 1". From ALMA Cycle0 data we found the FWHM source size to be ~ 0.4". The size of the source is expected to be smaller than the angular resolution requested. Since this is a detection project, the requested angular resolution allows to obtain good phase coherence in the observations.

For the CO(14-13) we expect a peak flux density of 320 microJy. Being a detection project, we request an rms of 61 microJy over the FWHM of the line (537 km/s) to reach a 5.2 sigma detection on the integrated line.
With this sensitivity we expect to detect the continuum at high confidence level (178 sigma).
Note that ALMA Cycle 2 data available for this source have reached a sensitivity of 0.12 mJy on 537 km/s. With ALMA Cycle 3 observations we will get a factor of 2 higher sensitivity, i.e. duplication conditions do not apply to this project.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(14-13) J2310
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main goal is to detect the CO(14-13) in J2310. The required observations will allow us to constrain the ISM properties and the excitation conditions of the molecular gas in J2310.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Using the [CII] line redshift resulting from ALMA Cycle 0, we expect the CO(14-13) line to be at a frequency of 214.61924 GHz, that is the representative frequency of this Science Goal.
In the same sideband, we put one other SPW for the continuum determination.
Also the remaining two SPWs are used for the continuum determination and put in the other sideband.
The requested spectral resolution of 41 km/s is enough for the purpose of this Science Goal, since the FWHM of the line is expected to be ~ 456 km/s.

We request an angular resolution of 1". From ALMA Cycle 0 data we found the FWHM source size to be ~ 0.5". The size of the source is expected to be smaller than the angular resolution requested. Since this is a detection project, the requested angular resolution allows to obtain good phase coherence in the observations.

For the CO(14-13) line we expect a peak flux density of 1.8 mJy. Being a detection project, we request an rms of 357 microJy over the FWHM of the line (456 km/s) to reach a 5 sigma detection on the integrated line.
With this sensitivity we expect to detect the continuum at high confidence level (67 sigma).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(14-13) J2054
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main goal is to detect the CO(14-13) in J2054. The required observations will allow us to constrain the ISM properties and the excitation conditions of the molecular gas in J2054.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Although from Fig. 1 it can be seen that in this object CO lines with 11 < J < 13 can already conclusively discriminate between PDR and XDR models, there are no ALMA receivers that can detect these lines, since their observed frequencies fall between ALMA BAND4 and ALMA BAND6.
Using the [CII] line redshift resulting from ALMA Cycle 0 data, we expect the CO(14-13) line to be at a 244.34942 frequency GHz, that is the representative frequency of this Science Goal.
In the same side band, we put one other SPW for the continuum determination.
Also the two remaining SPWs are used for continuum determination and put on the other sideband.
The requested spectral resolution of 41 km/s is enough for the purpose of this Science Goal, since the FWHM is expected to be ~ 360 km/s.

We request an angular resolution of 1". From ALMA Cycle 0 data it results that the FWHM source size is ~ 0.3". The size of the source is expected to be smaller than the angular resolution requested. Since this is a detection project, the requested angular resolution allows to obtain good phase coherence in the observations.

For the CO(14-13) line we expect a peak flux density of 0.4 mJy. Being a detection project, we request an rms of 77 microJy over the FWHM of the line (360 km/s) to reach a 5.2 sigma detection on the integrated line.
With this sensitivity we expect to detect the continuum at high significance level (100 sigma).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(15-14) J0129
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main goal is to detect the CO(15-14) in J0129. The required observations will allow us to constrain the ISM properties and the excitation conditions of the molecular gas in J0129.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Using the [CII] line redshift resulting from ALMA Cycle 0 data, we expect the CO(15-14) line to be at 254.70998 GHz, that is the representative frequency of this Science Goal.
In the same side band we put one other SPW for the continuum determination.
Also the two remaining SPWs are used for continuum determination and put on the other sideband.
The requested spectral resolution of 37 km/s is enough for the purpose of this Science Goal, since the FWHM is expected to be ~ 283 km/s.

We request an angular resolution of 1". From ALMA Cycle 0 data it results that the FWHM source size is 0.3". The size of the source is expected to be smaller than the angular resolution requested. Since this is a detection project, the requested angular resolution allows to obtain good phase coherence in the observations.

For the CO(15-14) line we expect a peak flux density of 0.59 mJy. Being a detection project, we request an rms of 113 microJy over the FWHM of the line (283 km/s) to reach a 5.2 sigma detection on the integrated line.
With this sensitivity we expect to detect the continuum at high significance level (95 sigma).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(13-12) J1044
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The main goal is to detect the CO(13-12) in J1044. The required observations will allow us to constrain the ISM properties and the excitation conditions of the molecular gas in J1044.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Using the [CII] line redshift resulting from ALMA Cycle 0 data, we expect the CO(13-12) line to be at a frequency of 220.70696 GHz, that is the representative frequency of this Science Goal.
In the same sideband we put one other SPW for the continuum determination.
Also the two remaining SPWs are used for the continuum determination and put on the other sideband.
The requested spectral resolution of 42 km/s is enough for the purpose of this Science Goal, since the FWHM is expected to be ~ 160 km/s.

We request an angular resolution of 1". From ALMA Cycle 0 data it results that the FHWM source size is ~ 0.45. The size of the source is expected to be smaller than the angular resolution requested. Since this is a detection project, the requested angular resolution allows to obtain good phase coherence in the observations.

For the CO(13-12) line we expect a peak flux density of 0.59 mJy. Being a detection project, we request an rms of 113 microJy over the FWHM of the line (160 km/s) to reach a 5.2 sigma detection on the integrated line.
With this sensitivity we expect to detect the continuum at high significance level (61 sigma).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We have detected the CO(17-16) line in a quasar at z=6.4 through the PdBI. This is the most excited CO transition ever detected in such distant galaxies. The detection of such high-J CO line allows to put strong constraints on the properties of the molecular gas at high-z. Moreover, this discovery suggests that high-J CO lines may provide a sensitive, unique tool to infer the presence of X-ray faint or obscured super massive black hole progenitors in galaxies at z>6, thus shedding light on a key problem in cosmic structure formation. To test this exciting hypothesis it is necessary to deeply understand the physical mechanisms responsible for the excitation of high-J CO lines. We therefore propose to observe high-J CO lines in five z~6 quasars for which ALMA Cycle 0 observations are already available. The success of our experiment will strongly support the idea that high-J CO lines are specific signatures of high-z quasars, namely that AGN activity is always associated with high-J CO lines. The new capabilities offered by ALMA in Cycle 3 allow to open a new pathway for the discovery of SMBH progenitors in only 5.3 hours of on-source observing time.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Code: 2013.1.00462.S Title: Highly excited CO lines in quasars at z>6 PI: Simona Gallerani
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
